Brazil">numerous peaceful protests</a> erupted in Brazil from the middle of first term of <a href="/wiki/Dilma_Rousseff" title="Dilma Rousseff">Dilma Rousseff</a>, who succeeded Lula in the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_2010" title="Brazilian presidential election, 2010">in 2010</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> Enhanced by a political and economic crises with evidence of involvement by politicians from all the primary political parties in several <a href="/wiki/Bribery" title="Bribery">bribery</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tax_evasion" title="Tax evasion">tax evasion</a> schemes,<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_protests_in_Brazil" title="2015\xe2\x80\x9316 protests in Brazil">large street protests for and against her</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> Rousseff <a href="/wiki/Impeachment_of_Dilma_Rousseff" title="Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff">was impeached</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Congress" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian Congress">Brazilian Congress</a> in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> In 2017, the Supreme Court has asked for the investigation of 71 Brazilian lawmakers and nine ministers in President <a href="/wiki/Michel_Temer" title="Michel Temer">Michel Temer</a>\'s cabinet allegedly linked to the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Car_Wash" title="Operation Car Wash">Petrobras corruption scandal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> President Temer is himself accused of <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Brazil" title="Corruption in Brazil">corruption</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup></p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Brazil" title="Geography of Brazil">Geography of Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Brazil_topo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Brazil_topo.jpg/330px-Brazil_topo.jpg" width="330" height="334" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Brazil_topo.jpg/495px-Brazil_topo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Brazil_topo.jpg/660px-Brazil_topo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="1419" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Brazil_topo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nTopographic map of Brazil.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Brazil occupies a large area along the eastern coast of South America and includes much of the continent\'s interior,<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_6_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_6-155">[155]</a></sup> sharing land borders with <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> to the south; <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a> to the southwest; <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a> to the west; <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> to the northwest; and <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">Guyana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname">Suriname</a> and <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a> (French overseas region of <a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a>) to the north. It shares a border with every South American country except <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>. It also encompasses a number of oceanic <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelagos</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Fernando_de_Noronha" title="Fernando de Noronha">Fernando de Noronha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rocas_Atoll" title="Rocas Atoll">Rocas Atoll</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter_and_Saint_Paul_Archipelago" title="Saint Peter and Saint Paul Archipelago">Saint Peter and Paul Rocks</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Trindade_and_Martim_Vaz" class="mw-redirect" title="Trindade and Martim Vaz">Trindade and Martim Vaz</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_15-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-15">[15]</a></sup> Its size, relief, climate, and natural resources make Brazil geographically diverse.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_6_155-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_6-155">[155]</a></sup> Including its <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic</a> islands, Brazil lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/6th_parallel_north" title="6th parallel north">6\xc2\xb0N</a> and <a href="/wiki/34th_parallel_south" title="34th parallel south">34\xc2\xb0S</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/28th_meridian_west" title="28th meridian west">28\xc2\xb0</a> and <a href="/wiki/74th_meridian_west" title="74th meridian west">74\xc2\xb0W</a>.</p>\n<p>Brazil is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_total_area" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries and outlying territories by total area">fifth largest</a> country in the world, and third largest in the Americas, with a total area of 8,515,767.049&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (3,287,956&#160;sq&#160;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-Official_Area_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Official_Area-156">[156]</a></sup> including 55,455&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (21,411&#160;sq&#160;mi) of water.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_15-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-15">[15]</a></sup> It spans four <a href="/wiki/Time_zone" title="Time zone">time zones</a>; from <a href="/wiki/UTC-05" class="mw-redirect" title="UTC-05">UTC\xe2\x88\x925</a> comprising the state of <a href="/wiki/Acre_(state)" title="Acre (state)">Acre</a> and the westernmost portion of <a href="/wiki/Amazonas_(Brazilian_state)" title="Amazonas (Brazilian state)">Amazonas</a>, to <a href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9204" class="mw-redirect" title="UTC\xe2\x88\x9204">UTC\xe2\x88\x924</a> in the western states, to <a href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9203" class="mw-redirect" title="UTC\xe2\x88\x9203">UTC\xe2\x88\x923</a> in the eastern states (the <a href="/wiki/Time_in_Brazil" title="Time in Brazil">national time</a>) and <a href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9202" class="mw-redirect" title="UTC\xe2\x88\x9202">UTC\xe2\x88\x922</a> in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Brazil" title="List of islands of Brazil">Atlantic islands</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-timezones_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timezones-157">[157]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Brazil is the only country in the world that has the <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">equator</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tropic_of_Capricorn" title="Tropic of Capricorn">Tropic of Capricorn</a> running through it. It is also the only country to have contiguous territory both inside and outside the tropics. Brazilian topography is also diverse and includes hills, mountains, plains, highlands, and scrublands. Much of the terrain lies between 200 metres (660&#160;ft) and 800 metres (2,600&#160;ft) in elevation.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-158">[158]</a></sup> The main upland area occupies most of the southern half of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_158-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-158">[158]</a></sup> The northwestern parts of the plateau consist of broad, rolling terrain broken by low, rounded hills.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_158-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-158">[158]</a></sup></p>\n<p>The southeastern section is more rugged, with a complex mass of ridges and mountain ranges reaching elevations of up to 1,200 metres (3,900&#160;ft).<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_158-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-158">[158]</a></sup> These ranges include the <a href="/wiki/Mantiqueira_Mountains" title="Mantiqueira Mountains">Mantiqueira</a> and <a href="/wiki/Espinha%C3%A7o_Mountains" title="Espinha\xc3\xa7o Mountains">Espinha\xc3\xa7o mountains</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Serra_do_Mar" title="Serra do Mar">Serra do Mar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_158-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-158">[158]</a></sup> In the north, the <a href="/wiki/Guiana_Shield" title="Guiana Shield">Guiana Highlands</a> form a major drainage divide, separating rivers that flow south into the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Basin" class="mw-redirect" title="Amazon Basin">Amazon Basin</a> from rivers that empty into the <a href="/wiki/Orinoco" title="Orinoco">Orinoco River</a> system, in Venezuela, to the north. The highest point in Brazil is the <a href="/wiki/Pico_da_Neblina" title="Pico da Neblina">Pico da Neblina</a> at 2,994 metres (9,823&#160;ft), and the lowest is the Atlantic Ocean.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_15-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-15">[15]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Brazil has a dense and complex system of rivers, one of the world\'s most extensive, with eight major drainage basins, all of which drain into the Atlantic.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_8_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_8-159">[159]</a></sup> Major rivers include the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_River" title="Amazon River">Amazon</a> (the world\'s second-longest river and the largest in terms of volume of water), the <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_River" title="Paran\xc3\xa1 River">Paran\xc3\xa1</a> and its major tributary the <a href="/wiki/Iguazu_River" title="Iguazu River">Igua\xc3\xa7u</a> (which includes the <a href="/wiki/Iguazu_Falls" title="Iguazu Falls">Iguazu Falls</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Rio_Negro_(Amazon)" title="Rio Negro (Amazon)">Negro</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Francisco_River" title="S\xc3\xa3o Francisco River">S\xc3\xa3o Francisco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xingu_River" title="Xingu River">Xingu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madeira_River" title="Madeira River">Madeira</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tapaj%C3%B3s" title="Tapaj\xc3\xb3s">Tapaj\xc3\xb3s</a> rivers.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_8_159-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_8-159">[159]</a></sup></p>\n<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed" style="font-size:88%;line-height:120%">\n<li class=\'gallerycaption\'>Geography of Brazil</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px">\n<div style="width: 182px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a style="width: 182px">\n<div style="width: 182px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Morro_do_Pai_In%C3%A1cio_01.jpg" class="image"><img Park</a> in <a href="/wiki/Piau%C3%AD" title="Piau\xc3\xad">Piau\xc3\xad</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 256px">\n<div style="width: 256px">\n<div class="thumb" Grosso do Sul">Mato Grosso do Sul</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 206px">\n<div style="width: 206px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 204px;">\n<div National Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maranh%C3%A3o" title="Maranh\xc3\xa3o">Maranh\xc3\xa3o</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 186px">\n<div style="width: 186px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 184px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Simone_Marinho_-_Trindade_-_2010_05_08_edited.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" data-file-height="2340" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Trindade_and_Martin_Vaz" title="Trindade and Martin Vaz">Trindade and Martin Vaz</a> is a volcanic archipelago off the coast of Brazil.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 126.66666666667px">\n<div style="width: 126.66666666667px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 124.66666666667px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pico_da_Neblina.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Pico_da_Neblina.jpg/187px-Pico_da_Neblina.jpg" width="125" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Pico_da_Neblina.jpg/280px-Pico_da_Neblina.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Pico_da_Neblina.jpg/373px-Pico_da_Neblina.jpg 2x" data-file-width="573" data-file-height="553" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Pico_da_Neblina" title="Pico da Neblina">Pico da Neblina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amazonas_(Brazilian_state)" title="Amazonas (Brazilian state)">Amazonas</a>, the highest mountain in Brazil.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px">\n<div style="width: 182px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cataratas.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cataratas.jpg/270px-Cataratas.jpg" width="180" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cataratas.jpg/405px-Cataratas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cataratas.jpg/540px-Cataratas.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3961" data-file-height="2644" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Iguazu_Falls" title="Iguazu Falls">Iguazu Falls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_(state)" title="Paran\xc3\xa1 (state)">Paran\xc3\xa1</a>, is the largest waterfalls system in the world.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 167.33333333333px">\n<div style="width: 167.33333333333px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 165.33333333333px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pantanal,_south-central_South_America_5170.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Pantanal%2C_south-central_South_America_5170.jpg/248px-Pantanal%2C_south-central_South_America_5170.jpg" width="166" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Pantanal%2C_south-central_South_America_5170.jpg/372px-Pantanal%2C_south-central_South_America_5170.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Pantanal%2C_south-central_South_America_5170.jpg/496px-Pantanal%2C_south-central_South_America_5170.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1101" data-file-height="799" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Pantanal" title="Pantanal">Pantanal</a>, flooded grasslands and savannas in <a href="/wiki/Mato_Grosso_do_Sul" title="Mato Grosso do Sul">Mato Grosso do Sul</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Brazil" title="Climate of Brazil">Climate of Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Koppen_climate_classification_Brazil.tif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Koppen_climate_classification_Brazil.tif/lossless-page1-290px-Koppen_climate_classification_Brazil.tif.png" width="290" height="278" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Koppen_climate_classification_Brazil.tif/lossless-page1-435px-Koppen_climate_classification_Brazil.tif.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Koppen_climate_classification_Brazil.tif/lossless-page1-580px-Koppen_climate_classification_Brazil.tif.png 2x" data-file-width="2617" data-file-height="2508" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Koppen_climate_classification_Brazil.tif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nBrazil map of <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="K\xc3\xb6ppen climate classification">K\xc3\xb6ppen climate classification</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The climate of Brazil comprises a wide range of weather conditions across a large area and varied topography, but most of the country is tropical.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_15-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-15">[15]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="K\xc3\xb6ppen climate classification">K\xc3\xb6ppen system</a>, Brazil hosts six major climatic subtypes: <a href="/wiki/Desert_climate" title="Desert climate">desert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tropical_rainforest_climate" title="Tropical rainforest climate">equatorial</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tropical_climate" title="Tropical climate">tropical</a>, <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semiarid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">subtropical</a>. The different climatic conditions produce environments ranging from <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_moist_broadleaf_forests" title="Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests">equatorial rainforests</a> in the north and semiarid deserts in the northeast, to <a href="/wiki/Temperate_coniferous_forest" title="Temperate coniferous forest">temperate coniferous forests</a> in the south and <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_grasslands,_savannas,_and_shrublands" title="Tropical and subtropical grasslands, savannas, and shrublands">tropical savannas</a> in central Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-160">[160]</a></sup> Many regions have starkly different <a href="/wiki/Microclimate" title="Microclimate">microclimates</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-161">[161]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BT_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BT-162">[162]</a></sup></p>\n<p>An equatorial climate characterizes much of northern Brazil. There is no real <a href="/wiki/Dry_season" title="Dry season">dry season</a>, but there are some variations in the period of the year when most rain falls.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_160-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-160">[160]</a></sup> Temperatures average 25&#160;\xc2\xb0C (77&#160;\xc2\xb0F),<sup id="cite_ref-BT_162-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BT-162">[162]</a></sup> with more significant temperature variation between night and day than between seasons.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_161-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-161">[161]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Over central Brazil rainfall is more seasonal, characteristic of a savanna climate.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_161-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-161">[161]</a></sup> This region is as extensive as the Amazon basin but has a very different climate as it lies farther south at a higher altitude.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_160-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-160">[160]</a></sup> In the interior northeast, seasonal rainfall is even more extreme. The semiarid climatic region generally receives less than 800 millimetres (31.5&#160;in) of rain,<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> most of which generally falls in a period of three to five months of the year<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup> and occasionally less than this, creating long periods of drought.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_161-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-161">[161]</a></sup> Brazil\'s 1877\xe2\x80\x9378 <i><a href="/wiki/Grande_Seca" title="Grande Seca">Grande Seca</a></i> (Great Drought), the worst in Brazil\'s history,<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup> caused approximately half a million deaths.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> A similarly devastating drought occurred in 1915.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup></p>\n<p>South of Bahia, near the coasts, and more southerly most of the state of S\xc3\xa3o Paulo, the distribution of rainfall changes, with rain falling throughout the year.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_160-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-160">[160]</a></sup> The south enjoys subtropical conditions, with cool winters and average annual temperatures not exceeding 18&#160;\xc2\xb0C (64.4&#160;\xc2\xb0F);<sup id="cite_ref-BT_162-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BT-162">[162]</a></sup> winter frosts and <a href="/wiki/Snow_in_Brazil" title="Snow in Brazil">snowfall</a> are not rare in the highest areas.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_160-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-160">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_161-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-161">[161]</a></sup></p>\n<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">\n<li class=\'gallerycaption\'>Climate of Brazil</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182.66666666667px">\n<div style="width: 182.66666666667px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 180.66666666667px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Neve_na_SC-438_em_S%C3%A3o_Joaquim.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Neve_na_SC-438_em_S%C3%A3o_Joaquim.JPG/271px-Neve_na_SC-438_em_S%C3%A3o_Joaquim.JPG" width="181" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Neve_na_SC-438_em_S%C3%A3o_Joaquim.JPG/406px-Neve_na_SC-438_em_S%C3%A3o_Joaquim.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Neve_na_SC-438_em_S%C3%A3o_Joaquim.JPG/542px-Neve_na_SC-438_em_S%C3%A3o_Joaquim.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3008" data-file-height="2000" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Snow_in_Brazil" title="Snow in Brazil">Snow</a> in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Joaquim" title="S\xc3\xa3o Joaquim">S\xc3\xa3o Joaquim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santa_Catarina_(state)" title="Santa Catarina (state)">Santa Catarina</a>, with an <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 187.33333333333px">\n<div style="width: 187.33333333333px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 185.33333333333px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Intervales_-_mirante_da_anta.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Intervales_-_mirante_da_anta.jpg/555px-Intervales_-_mirante_da_anta.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1800" data-file-height="1168" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">Subtropical climate</a> in <a href="/wiki/Intervales_State_Park" title="Intervales State Park">Intervales State Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo (state)">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182.66666666667px">\n<div style="width: 182.66666666667px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 180.66666666667px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Praia_do_Forno_-_Arraial.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Praia_do_Forno_-_Arraial.jpg/271px-Praia_do_Forno_-_Arraial.jpg" class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Tropical_climate" title="Tropical climate">Tropical climate</a> in <a href="/wiki/Arraial_do_Cabo" title="Arraial do Cabo">Arraial do Cabo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_(state)" title="Rio de Janeiro (state)">Rio de Janeiro</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">\n<div style="width: 162px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Meeting_of_waters_from_the_air_manaus_brazil.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Meeting_of_waters_from_the_air_manaus_brazil.JPG/240px-Meeting_of_waters_from_the_air_manaus_brazil.JPG" width="160" height="120" //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Meeting_of_waters_from_the_air_manaus_brazil.JPG/480px-Meeting_of_waters_from_the_air_manaus_brazil.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2816" data-file-height="2112" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Equatorial_climate" class="mw-redirect" title="Equatorial climate">Equatorial climate</a> in <a href="/wiki/Meeting_of_Waters" title="Meeting of Waters">Meeting of Waters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amazonas_(Brazilian_state)" title="Amazonas (Brazilian state)">Amazonas</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px">\n<div style="width: 182px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pedra_Furada_-_Serra_da_Capivara_I.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Pedra_Furada_-_Serra_da_Capivara_I.jpg/270px-Pedra_Furada_-_Serra_da_Capivara_I.jpg" width="180" height="120" //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Pedra_Furada_-_Serra_da_Capivara_I.jpg/540px-Pedra_Furada_-_Serra_da_Capivara_I.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4752" data-file-height="3168" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">Semi-arid climate</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Serra_da_Capivara_National_Park" title="Serra da Capivara National Park">Serra da Capivara National Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piau%C3%AD" title="Piau\xc3\xad">Piau\xc3\xad</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">\n<div style="width: 162px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Morro_cabeludo_-_Parque_dos_Pireneus_-_Piren%C3%B3polis_-_Goi%C3%A1s_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Morro_cabeludo_-_Parque_dos_Pireneus_-_Piren%C3%B3polis_-_Goi%C3%A1s_01.jpg/240px-Morro_cabeludo_-_Parque_dos_Pireneus_-_Piren%C3%B3polis_-_Goi%C3%A1s_01.jpg" width="160" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Morro_cabeludo_-_Parque_dos_Pireneus_-_Piren%C3%B3polis_-_Goi%C3%A1s_01.jpg/360px-Morro_cabeludo_-_Parque_dos_Pireneus_-_Piren%C3%B3polis_-_Goi%C3%A1s_01.jpg 1.5x, 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3000" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Tropical_savanna_climate" title="Tropical savanna climate">Tropical savanna climate</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cerrado" title="Cerrado">Cerrado</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pirineus_State_Park" title="Pirineus State Park">Pirineus State Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piren%C3%B3polis" title="Piren\xc3\xb3polis">Piren\xc3\xb3polis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goi%C3%A1s" title="Goi\xc3\xa1s">Goi\xc3\xa1s</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity_and_environment">Biodiversity and environment</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Brazil" title="Wildlife of Brazil">Wildlife of Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deforestation_in_Brazil" title="Deforestation in Brazil">Deforestation in Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Conservation_in_Brazil" title="Conservation in Brazil">Conservation in Brazil</a></div>\n<p>Brazil\'s large territory comprises different ecosystems, such as the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">Amazon rainforest</a>, recognized as having the greatest <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biological diversity</a> in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-WWF_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WWF-168">[168]</a></sup> with the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Forest" title="Atlantic Forest">Atlantic Forest</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Cerrado" title="Cerrado">Cerrado</a>, sustaining the greatest biodiversity.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_10_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_10-169">[169]</a></sup> In the south, the <a href="/wiki/Araucaria" title="Araucaria">Araucaria</a> pine forest grows under temperate conditions.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_10_169-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_10-169">[169]</a></sup> The rich wildlife of Brazil reflects the variety of natural habitats. Scientists estimate that the total number of <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Brazil" title="Wildlife of Brazil">plant</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Brazil" title="Wildlife of Brazil">animal species</a> in Brazil could approach four million, mostly invertebrates.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_10_169-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_10-169">[169]</a></sup></p>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Amazon_CIAT_(5).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg/220px-Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg/330px-Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg/440px-Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Amazon_CIAT_(5).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nThe <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">Amazon rainforest</a>, the richest and most biodiverse rainforest in the world.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Larger mammals include carnivores <a href="/wiki/Cougar" title="Cougar">pumas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaguar" title="Jaguar">jaguars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ocelot" title="Ocelot">ocelots</a>, rare <a href="/wiki/Bush_dog" title="Bush dog">bush dogs</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fox" title="Fox">foxes</a>, and herbivores <a href="/wiki/Peccary" title="Peccary">peccaries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tapir" title="Tapir">tapirs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anteater" title="Anteater">anteaters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sloth" title="Sloth">sloths</a>, <a href="/wiki/Opossum" title="Opossum">opossums</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Armadillo" title="Armadillo">armadillos</a>. <a href="/wiki/Deer" title="Deer">Deer</a> are plentiful in the south, and many species of <a href="/wiki/New_World_monkey" title="New World monkey">New World monkeys</a> are found in the northern <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rain forests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_10_169-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_10-169">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> Concern for the environment has grown in response to global interest in environmental issues.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_11_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_11-171">[171]</a></sup> Brazil\'s Amazon Basin is home to an extremely diverse array of fish species, including the <a href="/wiki/Red-bellied_piranha" title="Red-bellied piranha">red-bellied piranha</a>. Despite its reputation as a ferocious freshwater fish, the red-bellied piranha is actually a generally timid scavenger. Biodiversity can contribute to <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>, livestock, forestry and fisheries extraction. However, almost all economically exploited species of plants, such as soybeans and coffee, or animals, such as chickens, are imported from other countries, and the economic use of native species still crawls. In the Brazilian GDP, the forest sector represents just over 1% and fishing 0.4%.</p>\n<p>The natural heritage of Brazil is severely threatened by cattle ranching and agriculture, logging, mining, resettlement, oil and gas extraction, over-fishing, wildlife trade, dams and infrastructure, water pollution, climate change, fire, and invasive species.<sup id="cite_ref-WWF_168-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WWF-168">[168]</a></sup> In many areas of the country, the natural environment is threatened by development.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> Construction of highways has opened up previously remote areas for agriculture and settlement; dams have flooded valleys and inundated wildlife habitats; and mines have scarred and polluted the landscape.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_11_171-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_11-171">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> At least 70 dams are said to be planned for the Amazon region, including the controversial <a href="/wiki/Belo_Monte_Dam" title="Belo Monte Dam">Belo Monte</a> hydroelectric dam.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup></p>\n<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">\n<li class=\'gallerycaption\'>Biodiversity of Brazil</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 157.33333333333px">\n<div style="width: 157.33333333333px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 155.33333333333px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dendrobates_azureus_(Dendrobates_tinctorius)_Edit.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Dendrobates_azureus_%28Dendrobates_tinctorius%29_Edit.jpg/233px-Dendrobates_azureus_%28Dendrobates_tinctorius%29_Edit.jpg" width="156" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Dendrobates_azureus_%28Dendrobates_tinctorius%29_Edit.jpg/350px-Dendrobates_azureus_%28Dendrobates_tinctorius%29_Edit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Dendrobates_azureus_%28Dendrobates_tinctorius%29_Edit.jpg/466px-Dendrobates_azureus_%28Dendrobates_tinctorius%29_Edit.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2591" data-file-height="2002" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Blue_poison_dart_frog" title="Blue poison dart frog">Blue poison dart frog</a>, found in the forests of the far northern Brazil.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 152px">\n<div style="width: 152px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tucano%C3%A7u_-_Ramphastos_toco_06.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Tucano%C3%A7u_-_Ramphastos_toco_06.jpg/225px-Tucano%C3%A7u_-_Ramphastos_toco_06.jpg" width="150" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Tucano%C3%A7u_-_Ramphastos_toco_06.jpg/337px-Tucano%C3%A7u_-_Ramphastos_toco_06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Tucano%C3%A7u_-_Ramphastos_toco_06.jpg/450px-Tucano%C3%A7u_-_Ramphastos_toco_06.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1800" data-file-height="1441" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Toco_toucan" title="Toco toucan">Toco toucan</a>, a Brazilian symbol, a country with one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Brazil" title="List of birds of Brazil">largest variety of birds</a> in the world.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px">\n<div style="width: 182px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jaguar_(Panthera_onca_palustris)_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG/270px-Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG" width="180" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG/405px-Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG/540px-Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4769" data-file-height="3179" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p>Female <a href="/wiki/Pantanal_jaguar" title="Pantanal jaguar">pantanal jaguar</a> in <a href="/wiki/Piquir%C3%AD_River_(S%C3%A3o_Louren%C3%A7o)" title="Piquir\xc3\xad River (S\xc3\xa3o Louren\xc3\xa7o)">Piquir\xc3\xad River</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pantanal" title="Pantanal">Pantanal</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px">\n<div style="width: 182px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg/270px-Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg" width="180" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg/405px-Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg/540px-Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1772" data-file-height="1181" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Golden_lion_tamarin" title="Golden lion tamarin">Golden lion tamarin</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Endemic" class="mw-redirect" title="Endemic">endemic</a> animal of Brazil, in the <a href="/wiki/Po%C3%A7o_das_Antas_Biological_Reserve" title="Po\xc3\xa7o das Antas Biological Reserve">Po\xc3\xa7o das Antas Biological Reserve</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 184px">\n<div style="width: 184px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 182px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_%28cropped%29.jpg/273px-Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_%28cropped%29.jpg" width="182" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_%28cropped%29.jpg/409px-Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_%28cropped%29.jpg/545px-Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="637" data-file-height="421" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Lear%27s_macaw" title="Lear\'s macaw">Lear\'s macaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Endemic" class="mw-redirect" title="Endemic">endemic</a> to <a href="/wiki/Raso_da_Catarina" title="Raso da Catarina">Raso da Catarina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bahia" title="Bahia">Bahia</a>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 152px">\n<div style="width: 152px">\n<div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">\n<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maned_Wolf_11,_Beardsley_Zoo,_2009-11-06.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Maned_Wolf_11%2C_Beardsley_Zoo%2C_2009-11-06.jpg/225px-Maned_Wolf_11%2C_Beardsley_Zoo%2C_2009-11-06.jpg" width="150" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Maned_Wolf_11%2C_Beardsley_Zoo%2C_2009-11-06.jpg/338px-Maned_Wolf_11%2C_Beardsley_Zoo%2C_2009-11-06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Maned_Wolf_11%2C_Beardsley_Zoo%2C_2009-11-06.jpg/450px-Maned_Wolf_11%2C_Beardsley_Zoo%2C_2009-11-06.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3240" data-file-height="2592" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class="gallerytext">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Maned_Wolf" class="mw-redirect" title="Maned Wolf">Maned Wolf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Endemic" class="mw-redirect" title="Endemic">endemic</a> animal of <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Southeast Region, Brazil">southeastern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central-West_Region,_Brazil" title="Central-West Region, Brazil">central-western</a> regions.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Brazil" title="Politics of Brazil">Politics of Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_Brazil" title="Federal government of Brazil">Federal government of Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Brazil" title="Elections in Brazil">Elections in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg/220px-Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg/330px-Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg/440px-Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2048" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto" title="Pal\xc3\xa1cio do Planalto">Pal\xc3\xa1cio do Planalto</a> ("Plateau Palace"), the official workplace of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Brazil" title="President of Brazil">President of Brazil</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The form of government is that of a <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democratic</a> <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federative</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential system</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup> The president is both head of state and head of government of the Union and is elected for a four-year term,<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup> with the possibility of re-election for a second successive term. The current president is <a href="/wiki/Michel_Temer" title="Michel Temer">Michel Temer</a>, who replaced <a href="/wiki/Dilma_Rousseff" title="Dilma Rousseff">Dilma Rousseff</a> after her <a href="/wiki/Impeachment_of_Dilma_Rousseff" title="Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff">impeachment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-175">[175]</a></sup> The President appoints the <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_State" title="Minister of State">Ministers of State</a>, who assist in government.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup> Legislative houses in each political entity are the main source of law in Brazil. The <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">National Congress</a> is the Federation\'s bicameral legislature, consisting of the <a href="/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_of_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Chamber of Deputies of Brazil">Chamber of Deputies</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Senate of Brazil">Federal Senate</a>. Judiciary authorities exercise jurisdictional duties almost exclusively. Brazil is a <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democracy</a>, according to the <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a> 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup></p>\n<p>The Brazilian Federation is the "indissoluble union" of the States, the Municipalities and the Federal District.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup> The Union, the states and the Federal District, and the municipalities, are the "spheres of government". The <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federation</a> is set on five fundamental principles:<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup> sovereignty, citizenship, dignity of human beings, the social values of labour and freedom of enterprise, and political pluralism. The classic tripartite branches of government (executive, legislative and judicial under a checks and balances system) are formally established by the Constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup> The executive and legislative are organized <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">independently in all three spheres of government</a>, while the judiciary is organized only at the federal and state/Federal District spheres.</p>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg/220px-Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg" width="220" height="125" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg/330px-Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg/440px-Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1162" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">National Congress of Brazil</a>, seat of the <a href="/wiki/Legislative_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative branch">legislative branch</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>All members of the executive and legislative branches are directly elected.<sup id="cite_ref-embassy_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-embassy-177">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> Judges and other judicial officials are appointed after passing entry exams.<sup id="cite_ref-embassy_177-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-embassy-177">[177]</a></sup> For most of its democratic history, Brazil has had a multi-party system, proportional representation. Voting is compulsory for the literate between 18 and 70 years old and optional for illiterates and those between 16 and 18 or beyond 70.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Together with several smaller parties, four political parties stand out: <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_(Brazil)" title="Workers\' Party (Brazil)">Workers\' Party</a> (PT), <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Social_Democracy_Party" title="Brazilian Social Democracy Party">Brazilian Social Democracy Party</a> (PSDB), <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Democratic_Movement_Party" title="Brazilian Democratic Movement Party">Brazilian Democratic Movement Party</a> (PMDB) and <a href="/wiki/Democrats_(Brazil)" title="Democrats (Brazil)">Democrats</a> (DEM). Fifteen political parties are represented in Congress. It is common for politicians to switch parties, and thus the proportion of congressional seats held by particular parties changes regularly.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> Almost all governmental and administrative functions are exercised by authorities and agencies affiliated to the Executive.</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law">Law</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Brazil" title="Law of Brazil">Law of Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Brazil" title="Law enforcement in Brazil">Law enforcement in Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Brazil" title="Crime in Brazil">Crime in Brazil</a></div>\n<p>Brazilian law is based on the <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> legal system<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> concepts prevail over common law practice. Most of Brazilian law is codified, although non-codified statutes also represent a substantial part, playing a complementary role. Court decisions set out interpretive guidelines; however, they are seldom binding on other specific cases. Doctrinal works and the works of academic jurists have strong influence in law creation and in law cases.</p>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Supremo_Brasil.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supremo_Brasil.jpg/220px-Supremo_Brasil.jpg" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supremo_Brasil.jpg/330px-Supremo_Brasil.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supremo_Brasil.jpg/440px-Supremo_Brasil.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2896" data-file-height="1944" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Supremo_Brasil.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/Supreme_Federal_Court_of_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Federal Court of Brazil">Supreme Federal Court of Brazil</a> serves primarily as the Constitutional Court of the country.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The legal system is based on the Federal Constitution, which was promulgated on 5 October 1988, and is the fundamental law of Brazil. All other legislation and court decisions must conform to its rules.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> As of April 2007<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Brazil&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there have been 53 amendments. States have their own constitutions, which must not contradict the Federal Constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> Municipalities and the Federal District have "organic laws" (<span lang="pt"><i>leis org\xc3\xa2nicas</i></span>), which act in a similar way to constitutions.<sup id="cite_ref-DeffentiBarral2011_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DeffentiBarral2011-184">[184]</a></sup> Legislative entities are the main source of statutes, although in certain matters judiciary and executive bodies may enact legal norms.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup> Jurisdiction is administered by the judiciary entities, although in rare situations the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Federal Constitution</a> allows the Federal Senate to pass on legal judgments.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup> There are also specialized military, labor, and electoral courts.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup> The highest court is the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Federal_Court" title="Supreme Federal Court">Supreme Federal Court</a>.</p>\n<p>This system has been criticized over the last few decades for the slow pace of decision-making. Lawsuits on appeal may take several years to resolve, and in some cases more than a decade elapses before definitive rulings.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup> Nevertheless, the Supreme Federal Tribunal was the first court in the world to transmit its sessions on television, and also via <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> More recently, in December 2009, the Supreme Court adopted <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a> to display items on the day planner of the ministers, to inform the daily actions of the Court and the most important decisions made by them.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Armed_Forces" title="Brazilian Armed Forces">Brazilian Armed Forces</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_100316-N-9116F-001_A_Brazilian_U.N._peacekeeper_walks_with_Haitian_children_during_a_patrol_in_Cite_Soleil.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/US_Navy_100316-N-9116F-001_A_Brazilian_U.N._peacekeeper_walks_with_Haitian_children_during_a_patrol_in_Cite_Soleil.jpg/220px-US_Navy_100316-N-9116F-001_A_Brazilian_U.N._peacekeeper_walks_with_Haitian_children_during_a_patrol_in_Cite_Soleil.jpg" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/US_Navy_100316-N-9116F-001_A_Brazilian_U.N._peacekeeper_walks_with_Haitian_children_during_a_patrol_in_Cite_Soleil.jpg/330px-US_Navy_100316-N-9116F-001_A_Brazilian_U.N._peacekeeper_walks_with_Haitian_children_during_a_patrol_in_Cite_Soleil.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/US_Navy_100316-N-9116F-001_A_Brazilian_U.N._peacekeeper_walks_with_Haitian_children_during_a_patrol_in_Cite_Soleil.jpg/440px-US_Navy_100316-N-9116F-001_A_Brazilian_U.N._peacekeeper_walks_with_Haitian_children_during_a_patrol_in_Cite_Soleil.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3965" data-file-height="2832" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_100316-N-9116F-001_A_Brazilian_U.N._peacekeeper_walks_with_Haitian_children_during_a_patrol_in_Cite_Soleil.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Army" title="Brazilian Army">Brazilian Army</a> participating in a <a href="/wiki/UN_peacekeeping" class="mw-redirect" title="UN peacekeeping">UN peacekeeping</a> mission in <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">Haiti</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The armed forces of Brazil are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel" title="List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel">second largest</a> in Latin America by active personnel and the largest in terms of military equipment.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> It consists of the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Army" title="Brazilian Army">Brazilian Army</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Army_Aviation_Command" title="Brazilian Army Aviation Command">Army Aviation Command</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Navy" title="Brazilian Navy">Brazilian Navy</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Marine_Corps" title="Brazilian Marine Corps">Marine Corps</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Naval_Aviation" title="Brazilian Naval Aviation">Naval Aviation</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Air_Force" title="Brazilian Air Force">Brazilian Air Force</a>. Brazil\'s <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscription</a> policy gives it one of the world\'s largest military forces, estimated at more than 1.6 million <a href="/wiki/Military_Reserve" class="mw-redirect" title="Military Reserve">reservist</a> annually.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Numbering close to 236,000 active personnel,<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> the Brazilian Army has the largest number of armored vehicles in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>, including armored transports and <a href="/wiki/Battle_tank" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle tank">tanks</a><sup id="cite_ref-militarypower1_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-militarypower1-192">[192]</a></sup> It is also unique in Latin America for its large, elite forces specializing in unconventional missions, the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Special_Operations_Command" title="Brazilian Special Operations Command">Brazilian Special Operations Command</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> and the versatile Strategic Rapid Action Force, made up of highly mobilized and prepared (Special Operations Brigade, <a href="/wiki/Parachute_Infantry_Brigade_(Brazil)" title="Parachute Infantry Brigade (Brazil)">Infantry Brigade Parachutist</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> 1st Jungle Infantry Battalion (Airmobile)<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> and 12th Brigade Light Infantry (Airmobile)<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> able to act anywhere in the country, on short notice, to counter external aggression.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> The states\' <a href="/wiki/Military_Police_(Brazil)" title="Military Police (Brazil)">Military Police</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Military_Firefighters_Corps" title="Military Firefighters Corps">Military Firefighters Corps</a> are described as an ancillary forces of the Army by the constitution, but are under the control of each state\'s governor.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup></p>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Various_aircraft_participate_in_the_Cruzeiro_Do_Sul_2010_exercises.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Various_aircraft_participate_in_the_Cruzeiro_Do_Sul_2010_exercises.jpg/330px-Various_aircraft_participate_in_the_Cruzeiro_Do_Sul_2010_exercises.jpg" width="330" height="135" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Various_aircraft_participate_in_the_Cruzeiro_Do_Sul_2010_exercises.jpg/495px-Various_aircraft_participate_in_the_Cruzeiro_Do_Sul_2010_exercises.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Various_aircraft_participate_in_the_Cruzeiro_Do_Sul_2010_exercises.jpg/660px-Various_aircraft_participate_in_the_Cruzeiro_Do_Sul_2010_exercises.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3600" data-file-height="1473" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Various_aircraft_participate_in_the_Cruzeiro_Do_Sul_2010_exercises.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nVarious aircraft participate in the <a href="/wiki/South_America_air_forces_maneuvers" title="South America air forces maneuvers">CRUZEX</a> exercise on 11 November 2010, at <a href="/wiki/Natal_Air_Force_Base" title="Natal Air Force Base">Natal Air Force Base</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The Navy once operated some of the most powerful warships in the world with the two <a href="/wiki/Minas_Geraes-class_battleship" title="Minas Geraes-class battleship"><i>Minas Geraes</i>-class</a> <a href="/wiki/Dreadnought" title="Dreadnought">dreadnoughts</a>, which sparked a <a href="/wiki/South_American_dreadnought_race" title="South American dreadnought race">South American dreadnought race</a> between Argentina, Brazil, and Chile.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> Today, it is a <a href="/wiki/Green-water_navy" title="Green-water navy">green water</a> force and has a group of specialized elite in retaking ships and naval facilities, <a href="/wiki/GRUMEC" title="GRUMEC">GRUMEC</a>, unit specially trained to protect Brazilian oil platforms along its coast.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> It\'s the only navy in Latin America that operates an <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">aircraft carrier</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_aircraft_carrier_S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(A12)" title="Brazilian aircraft carrier S\xc3\xa3o Paulo (A12)">NAe S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup> and one of the ten navies of the world to operate this type of ship.<sup id="cite_ref-militarypower1_192-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-militarypower1-192">[192]</a></sup></p>\n<p>The Air Force, it is the largest in Latin America has about 700 manned aircraft in service and effective about 67,000 personnel.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Brazil has not been invaded since 1865 during the <a href="/wiki/Paraguayan_War" title="Paraguayan War">Paraguayan War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> Additionally, Brazil has no contested territorial disputes with any of its neighbours<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> and neither does it have rivalries, like Chile and Bolivia have with each other.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> The Brazilian military has also three times intervened militarily to overthrow the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Government of Brazil">Brazilian government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-revistaepoca.globo.com_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-revistaepoca.globo.com-209">[209]</a></sup> It has built a tradition of participating in UN <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> missions such as in <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">Haiti</a> and <a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">East Timor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup></p>\n<center>\n<table class="toccolours" style="float:center; margin:0 0 1em 1em; border:1px #ddd solid;">\n<caption><b>Brazilian Armed Forces</b></caption>\n<tr style="text-align:center;">\n<td style="width:220px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Astros_2020_(14360471744).jpg" class="image"><img alt="Tank." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Astros_2020_%2814360471744%29.jpg/147px-Astros_2020_%2814360471744%29.jpg" width="147" height="90" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Astros_2020_%2814360471744%29.jpg/220px-Astros_2020_%2814360471744%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Astros_2020_%2814360471744%29.jpg/293px-Astros_2020_%2814360471744%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3535" data-file-height="2172" /></a><br />\n<small><a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Army" title="Brazilian Army">Brazilian Army</a><br />\n<a href="/wiki/Astros_II_MLRS" title="Astros II MLRS">Astros 2020</a></small></td>\n<td style="width:220px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vertente_soberania.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Ship." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Vertente_soberania.jpg/135px-Vertente_soberania.jpg" width="135" height="90" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Vertente_soberania.jpg/203px-Vertente_soberania.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Vertente_soberania.jpg/270px-Vertente_soberania.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="853" /></a><br />\n<small><a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Navy" title="Brazilian Navy">Brazilian Navy</a><br />\n<a href="/wiki/Brazilian_corvette_Barroso_(V34)" title="Brazilian corvette Barroso (V34)">Cv <i>Barroso</i> (V34)</a></small></td>\n<td style="width:220px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Brazilian_Air_Force_AMX_air-to-air_refuelling.jpg" class="image"><img alt="A-4AR Fightinghawk" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Brazilian_Air_Force_AMX_air-to-air_refuelling.jpg/136px-Brazilian_Air_Force_AMX_air-to-air_refuelling.jpg" width="136" height="90" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Brazilian_Air_Force_AMX_air-to-air_refuelling.jpg/204px-Brazilian_Air_Force_AMX_air-to-air_refuelling.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Brazilian_Air_Force_AMX_air-to-air_refuelling.jpg/271px-Brazilian_Air_Force_AMX_air-to-air_refuelling.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="850" /></a><br />\n<small><a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Air_Force" title="Brazilian Air Force">Brazilian Air Force</a><br />\n<a href="/wiki/AMX_International_AMX" title="AMX International AMX">AMX International</a></small></td>\n</tr>\n</table>\n</center>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_policy">Foreign policy</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Brazil" title="Foreign relations of Brazil">Foreign relations of Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Itamaraty.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Itamaraty.jpg/220px-Itamaraty.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Itamaraty.jpg/330px-Itamaraty.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Itamaraty.jpg/440px-Itamaraty.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Itamaraty.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/Itamaraty_Palace" title="Itamaraty Palace">Itamaraty Palace</a>, the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Brazil)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Brazil)">Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Brazil\'s international relations are based on Article 4 of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Federal Constitution</a>, which establishes <a href="/wiki/Non-interventionism" title="Non-interventionism">non-intervention</a>, <a href="/wiki/Self-determination" title="Self-determination">self-determination</a>, <a href="/wiki/Internationalism_(politics)" title="Internationalism (politics)">international cooperation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Peacebuilding" title="Peacebuilding">peaceful settlement of conflicts</a> as the guiding principles of Brazil\'s relationship with other countries and multilateral organizations.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup></p>\n<p>According to the Constitution, the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Brazil" title="President of Brazil">President</a> has ultimate authority over foreign policy, while the <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">Congress</a> is tasked with reviewing and considering all diplomatic nominations and <a href="/wiki/Treaty" title="Treaty">international treaties</a>, as well as legislation relating to Brazilian foreign policy.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Brazil\'s foreign policy is a by-product of the country\'s unique position as a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a> in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, a leader among <a href="/wiki/Developing_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="Developing countries">developing countries</a>, and an emerging <a href="/wiki/World_power" class="mw-redirect" title="World power">world power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> Brazilian foreign policy has generally been based on the principles of <a href="/wiki/Multilateralism" title="Multilateralism">multilateralism</a>, peaceful dispute settlement, and non-intervention in the affairs of other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup></p>\n<p>An increasingly well-developed tool of Brazil\'s foreign policy is providing aid as a donor to other developing countries.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-215">[215]</a></sup> Brazil does not just use its growing economic strength to provide financial aid, but it also provides high levels of expertise and most importantly of all, a quiet non-confrontational diplomacy to improve governance levels.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_215-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-215">[215]</a></sup> Total aid is estimated to be around $1 billion per year that includes:<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_215-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-215">[215]</a></sup></p>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_missions_of_Brazil.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Diplomatic_missions_of_Brazil.png/330px-Diplomatic_missions_of_Brazil.png" width="330" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Diplomatic_missions_of_Brazil.png/495px-Diplomatic_missions_of_Brazil.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Diplomatic_missions_of_Brazil.png/660px-Diplomatic_missions_of_Brazil.png 2x" data-file-width="1425" data-file-height="625" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_missions_of_Brazil.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil" title="List of diplomatic missions in Brazil">Diplomatic missions of Brazil</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<ul>\n<li>technical cooperation of around $480 million ($30 million in 2010 provided directly by the Brazilian Cooperation Agency (ABC))</li>\n<li>an estimated $450 million for in-kind expertise provided by Brazilian institutions specialising in technical cooperation</li>\n</ul>\n<p>In addition, Brazil manages a peacekeeping mission in <a href="/wiki/2010_Haiti_earthquake" title="2010 Haiti earthquake">Haiti</a> ($350 million) and makes in-kind contributions to the <a href="/wiki/World_Food_Programme" title="World Food Programme">World Food Programme</a> ($300 million).<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_215-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-215">[215]</a></sup> This is in addition to humanitarian assistance and contributions to multilateral development agencies. The scale of this aid places it on par with China and India.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_215-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-215">[215]</a></sup> The Brazilian South-South aid has been described as a "global model in waiting."<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement_and_crime">Law enforcement and crime</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Brazil" title="Law enforcement in Brazil">Law enforcement in Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Brazil" title="Crime in Brazil">Crime in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Helic%C3%B3ptero_PF.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Helic%C3%B3ptero_PF.jpg/220px-Helic%C3%B3ptero_PF.jpg" width="220" height="141" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Helic%C3%B3ptero_PF.jpg/330px-Helic%C3%B3ptero_PF.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Helic%C3%B3ptero_PF.jpg/440px-Helic%C3%B3ptero_PF.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3603" data-file-height="2309" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Helic%C3%B3ptero_PF.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nHelicopter of the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Police_Department" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal Police Department">Federal Police Department</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>In Brazil, the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Constitution</a> establishes five different police agencies for law enforcement: <a href="/wiki/Federal_Police_Department" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal Police Department">Federal Police Department</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_Highway_Police" title="Federal Highway Police">Federal Highway Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_Railroad_Police" title="Federal Railroad Police">Federal Railroad Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/Military_Police_(Brazil)" title="Military Police (Brazil)">Military Police</a> and <a href="/wiki/Civil_Police_(Brazil)" title="Civil Police (Brazil)">Civil Police</a>. Of these, the first three are affiliated with federal authorities and the last two are subordinate to state governments. All police forces are the responsibility of the executive branch of any of the federal or state powers.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Public_Security_Force" title="National Public Security Force">National Public Security Force</a> also can act in public disorder situations arising anywhere in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup></p>\n<p>The country still has above-average levels of violent crime and particularly high levels of gun violence and homicide. In 2012, the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO) estimated the number of 32 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants, one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_intentional_homicide_rate" title="List of countries by intentional homicide rate">highest rates of intentional homicide of the world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> The number considered tolerable by the WHO is about 10 homicides per 100,000 inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> However, there are differences between the crime rates in the <a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">Brazilian states</a>. While in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo (state)">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a> the homicide rate registered in 2013 was 10.8 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants, in <a href="/wiki/Alagoas" title="Alagoas">Alagoas</a> it was 64.7 homicides per 100,000 inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Brazil also has high levels of incarceration and the third largest prison population in the world (behind only <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>), with an estimated total of approximately 700,000 prisoners around the country (June 2014), an increase of about 300% compared to the index registered in 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> The high number of prisoners eventually overloaded the Brazilian prison system, leading to a shortfall of about two hundred thousand accommodations.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>\n<table class="infobox">\n<tr>\n<td>\n<div role="img" class="noresize" style="width: 400px; float: none; clear: none; font-size: 85%; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative; max-width: 100%; overflow-x: auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg/400px-Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg.png" width="400" height="352" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg/600px-Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg/800px-Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="780" data-file-height="687" /></a>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:330px; top:28px"><a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean"><i style="color: #333366;">Atlantic<br />\nOcean</i></a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:10px; top:272px"><a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean"><i style="color: #333366;">Pacific<br />\nOcean</i></a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:294px; top:330px"><a href="/wiki/South_Region,_Brazil" title="South Region, Brazil">South Region</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:34px; top:124px"><a href="/wiki/Acre_(state)" title="Acre (state)">Acre</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:74px; top:80px"><a href="/wiki/Amazonas_(Brazilian_state)" title="Amazonas (Brazilian state)">Amazonas</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:186px; top:80px"><a href="/wiki/Par%C3%A1" title="Par\xc3\xa1">Par\xc3\xa1</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:102px; top:24px"><a href="/wiki/Roraima" title="Roraima">Roraima</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:186px; top:30px"><a href="/wiki/Amap%C3%A1" title="Amap\xc3\xa1">Amap\xc3\xa1</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:90px; top:148px"><a href="/wiki/Rond%C3%B4nia" title="Rond\xc3\xb4nia">Rond\xc3\xb4nia</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:212px; top:136px"><a href="/wiki/Tocantins_(state)" class="mw-redirect" title="Tocantins (state)">Tocantins</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:238px; top:92px"><a href="/wiki/Maranh%C3%A3o" title="Maranh\xc3\xa3o">Maranh\xc3\xa3o</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:274px; top:152px"><a href="/wiki/Bahia" title="Bahia">Bahia</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:274px; top:112px"><a href="/wiki/Piau%C3%AD" title="Piau\xc3\xad">Piau\xc3\xad</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:294px; top:84px"><a href="/wiki/Cear%C3%A1" title="Cear\xc3\xa1">Cear\xc3\xa1</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:330px; top:84px"><a href="/wiki/Rio_Grande_do_Norte" title="Rio Grande do Norte">Rio Grande<br />\ndo Norte</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:334px; top:108px"><a href="/wiki/Para%C3%ADba" title="Para\xc3\xadba">Para\xc3\xadba</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:302px; top:120px"><a href="/wiki/Pernambuco" title="Pernambuco">Pernambuco</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:334px; top:132px"><a href="/wiki/Alagoas" title="Alagoas">Alagoas</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:322px; top:144px"><a href="/wiki/Sergipe" title="Sergipe">Sergipe</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:146px; top:164px"><a href="/wiki/Mato_Grosso" title="Mato Grosso">Mato Grosso</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;
