left:150px; top:224px"><a href="/wiki/Mato_Grosso_do_Sul" title="Mato Grosso do Sul">Mato Grosso<br />\ndo Sul</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:220px; top:172px"><a href="/wiki/Federal_District_(Brazil)" title="Federal District (Brazil)">Federal<br />\nDistrict</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:202px; top:196px"><a href="/wiki/Goi%C3%A1s" title="Goi\xc3\xa1s">Goi\xc3\xa1s</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:234px; top:216px"><a href="/wiki/Minas_Gerais" title="Minas Gerais">Minas Gerais</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:202px; top:240px"><a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo (state)">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:274px; top:244px"><a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_(state)" title="Rio de Janeiro (state)">Rio de Janeiro</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:294px; top:224px"><a href="/wiki/Esp%C3%ADrito_Santo" title="Esp\xc3\xadrito Santo">Esp\xc3\xadrito Santo</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:186px; top:264px"><a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_(state)" title="Paran\xc3\xa1 (state)">Paran\xc3\xa1</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:198px; top:284px"><a href="/wiki/Santa_Catarina_(state)" title="Santa Catarina (state)">Santa Catarina</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:166px; top:304px"><a href="/wiki/Rio_Grande_do_Sul" title="Rio Grande do Sul">Rio Grande<br />\ndo Sul</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:82px; top:312px"><i><a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Argentina</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:82px; top:196px"><i><a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Bolivia</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:50px; top:252px"><i><a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Chile</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:14px; top:20px"><i><a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Colombia</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:186px; top:4px"><i><a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">French Guiana</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:134px; top:20px"><i><a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Guyana</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:126px; top:248px"><i><a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Paraguay</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:14px; top:164px"><i><a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Peru</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:154px; top:12px"><i><a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Suriname</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:152px; top:336px"><i><a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Uruguay</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:74px; top:4px"><i><a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Venezuela</span></a></i></div>\n</div>\n<center><a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">States of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Brazil" title="Regions of Brazil">Regions of Brazil</a></center>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</table>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">States of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Brazil" title="Municipalities of Brazil">Municipalities of Brazil</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Brazil" title="Regions of Brazil">Regions of Brazil</a></div>\n<p>Brazil is a federation composed of 26 <a href="/wiki/Federated_state" title="Federated state">States</a>, one <a href="/wiki/Federal_District_(Brazil)" title="Federal District (Brazil)">Federal district</a> (which contains the capital city, <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Bras\xc3\xadlia">Bras\xc3\xadlia</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Municipality" title="Municipality">Municipalities</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup> States have autonomous administrations, collect their own taxes and receive a share of taxes collected by the Federal government. They have a governor and a unicameral legislative body elected directly by their voters. They also have independent Courts of Law for common justice. Despite this, states have much less autonomy to create their own laws than in the United States. For example, criminal and civil laws can be voted by only the federal bicameral Congress and are uniform throughout the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup></p>\n<p>The states and the federal district may be grouped into regions: <a href="/wiki/Northern_Region,_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern Region, Brazil">Northern</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Northeast Region, Brazil">Northeast</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central-West_Region,_Brazil" title="Central-West Region, Brazil">Central-West</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Southeast Region, Brazil">Southeast</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southern_Region,_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Southern Region, Brazil">Southern</a>. The Brazilian regions are merely geographical, not political or administrative divisions, and they do not have any specific form of government. Although defined by law, Brazilian regions are useful mainly for statistical purposes, and also to define the distribution of federal funds in development projects.</p>\n<p>Municipalities, as the states, have autonomous administrations, collect their own taxes and receive a share of taxes collected by the Union and state government.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o_17-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui.C3.A7.C3.A3o-17">[17]</a></sup> Each has a mayor and an elected legislative body, but no separate Court of Law. Indeed, a Court of Law organized by the state can encompass many municipalities in a single justice administrative division called <i><a href="/wiki/Comarca" title="Comarca">comarca</a></i> (county).</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Brazil" title="Economy of Brazil">Economy of Brazil</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_real" title="Brazilian real">Brazilian real</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tmulti tleft">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:443px;max-width:443px">\n<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:237px;max-width:237px">\n<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg/235px-Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg" width="235" height="125" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg/353px-Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg/470px-Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3612" data-file-height="1918" /></a></div>\n<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Quotes panel of <a href="/wiki/BM%26F_Bovespa" class="mw-redirect" title="BM&amp;F Bovespa">BM&amp;F Bovespa</a>, in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a>, the country\'s <a href="/wiki/Stock_exchange" title="Stock exchange">stock exchange</a>.</div>\n</div>\n<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">\n<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_(15414135738).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_%2815414135738%29.jpg/200px-Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_%2815414135738%29.jpg" width="200" height="126" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_%2815414135738%29.jpg/300px-Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_%2815414135738%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_%2815414135738%29.jpg/400px-Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_%2815414135738%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1800" data-file-height="1136" /></a></div>\n<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">\n<center>A <a href="/wiki/Embraer_KC-390" title="Embraer KC-390">KC-390</a> <a href="/wiki/Military_transport_aircraft" title="Military transport aircraft">military transport aircraft</a>, developed by Brazilian company <a href="/wiki/Embraer" title="Embraer">Embraer</a>, the third largest producer of civil aircraft, after <a href="/wiki/Airbus" title="Airbus">Airbus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Boeing" title="Boeing">Boeing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup></center>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div style="clear:left"></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Brazil is the largest national economy in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">world\'s ninth largest economy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">eighth largest</a> in <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP) according to the 2017 estimates. Brazil has a <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> with abundant natural resources. After rapid growth in preceding decades, the country <a href="/wiki/2014%E2%80%932016_Brazilian_economic_recession" class="mw-redirect" title="2014\xe2\x80\x932016 Brazilian economic recession">entered an ongoing recession in 2014</a> amid a political corruption scandal and nationwide protests.</p>\n<p>Its GDP (PPP) per capita was $15,048 in 2016<sup id="cite_ref-imf_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf-224">[224]</a></sup> putting Brazil in the 77th position according to IMF data. Active in <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agricultural</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mining" title="Mining">mining</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing" title="Manufacturing">manufacturing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">service sectors</a> Brazil has a labor force of over a 107 million (ranking 6th worldwide) and unemployment of 6.2% (ranking 64th worldwide).<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_Econ_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Econ-225">[225]</a></sup> The country has been expanding its presence in international financial and <a href="/wiki/Commodity_market" title="Commodity market">commodities markets</a>, and is one of a group of four emerging economies called the <a href="/wiki/BRIC" title="BRIC">BRIC countries</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup> Brazil has been the world\'s largest <a href="/wiki/Coffee_production_in_Brazil" title="Coffee production in Brazil">producer of coffee</a> for the last 150 years.<sup id="cite_ref-Neilson102_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Neilson102-24">[24]</a></sup></p>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arroz_097.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Arroz_097.jpg/220px-Arroz_097.jpg" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Arroz_097.jpg/330px-Arroz_097.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Arroz_097.jpg/440px-Arroz_097.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1456" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Arroz_097.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/Combine_harvester" title="Combine harvester">Combine harvester</a> in a rice plantation in <a href="/wiki/Santa_Catarina_(state)" title="Santa Catarina (state)">Santa Catarina</a>. Brazil is the third largest exporter of agricultural products in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-exporta.C3.A7.C3.A3oagr.C3.ADcola_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-exporta.C3.A7.C3.A3oagr.C3.ADcola-227">[227]</a></sup></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Central_Bank_of_Brazil.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Central_Bank_of_Brazil.jpg/220px-Central_Bank_of_Brazil.jpg" width="220" height="303" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Central_Bank_of_Brazil.jpg/330px-Central_Bank_of_Brazil.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Central_Bank_of_Brazil.jpg/440px-Central_Bank_of_Brazil.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1783" data-file-height="2458" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Central_Bank_of_Brazil.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Brazil" title="Central Bank of Brazil">Central Bank of Brazil</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Bras\xc3\xadlia">Bras\xc3\xadlia</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Brazil has become the fourth largest car market in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup> Major export products include <a href="/wiki/Fixed-wing_aircraft" title="Fixed-wing aircraft">aircraft</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electrical_equipment" title="Electrical equipment">electrical equipment</a>, <a href="/wiki/Automobile" class="mw-redirect" title="Automobile">automobiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethanol_fuel" title="Ethanol fuel">ethanol</a>, <a href="/wiki/Textile" title="Textile">textiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Footwear" title="Footwear">footwear</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iron_ore" title="Iron ore">iron ore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steel" title="Steel">steel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orange_juice" title="Orange juice">orange juice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soybean" title="Soybean">soybeans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Corned_beef" title="Corned beef">corned beef</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup> In total, Brazil ranks 23rd worldwide in <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">value of exports</a>.</p>\n<p>Brazil pegged its currency, the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_real" title="Brazilian real">real</a>, to the U.S. dollar in 1994. However, after the <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">East Asian financial crisis</a>, the <a href="/wiki/1998_Russian_financial_crisis" title="1998 Russian financial crisis">Russian default</a> in 1998<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup> and the series of adverse financial events that followed it, the <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Brazil" title="Central Bank of Brazil">Central Bank of Brazil</a> temporarily changed its <a href="/wiki/Monetary_policy" title="Monetary policy">monetary policy</a> to a managed-float<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup> scheme while undergoing a <a href="/wiki/Currency_crisis" title="Currency crisis">currency crisis</a>, until definitively changing the exchange regime to <a href="/wiki/Free-float" class="mw-redirect" title="Free-float">free-float</a> in January 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Brazil received an International Monetary Fund rescue package in mid-2002 of $30.4&#160;billion,<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup> then a record sum. Brazil\'s central bank paid back the IMF loan in 2005, although it was not due to be repaid until 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> One of the issues the Central Bank of Brazil recently dealt with was an excess of speculative short-term capital inflows to the country, which may have contributed to a fall in the value of the U.S. dollar against the real during that period.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup> Nonetheless, <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> (FDI), related to long-term, less speculative investment in production, is estimated to be $193.8&#160;billion for 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> Inflation monitoring and control currently plays a major part in the Central bank\'s role of setting out short-term <a href="/wiki/Interest_rate" title="Interest rate">interest rates</a> as a monetary policy measure.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Between 1993 and 2010, 7012 <a href="/wiki/Mergers_and_acquisitions" title="Mergers and acquisitions">mergers &amp; acquisitions</a> with a total known value of $707 billion with the involvement of Brazilian firms have been announced.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup> The year 2010 was a new record in terms of value with 115 billion USD of transactions. The largest transaction with involvement of Brazilian companies has been: <a href="/wiki/Vale_(mining_company)" class="mw-redirect" title="Vale (mining company)">Cia. Vale do Rio Doce</a> acquired <a href="/wiki/Vale_Inco" class="mw-redirect" title="Vale Inco">Inco</a> in a tender offer valued at US$18.9 billion.</p>\n<p>Corruption costs Brazil almost $41 billion a year alone, with 69.9% of the country\'s firms identifying the issue as a major constraint in successfully penetrating the global market.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> Local government corruption is so prevalent that voters perceive it as a problem only if it surpasses certain levels, and only if a local media e.g. a radio station is present to divulge the findings of corruption charges.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> Initiatives, like this exposure, strengthen awareness which is indicated by the Transparency International\'s <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>; ranking Brazil 69th out of 178 countries in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power" title="Purchasing power">purchasing power</a> in Brazil is eroded by the so-called <a href="/wiki/Brazil_cost" title="Brazil cost">Brazil cost</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-brcost_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brcost-242">[242]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Components_and_energy">Components and energy</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Brazil" title="Agriculture in Brazil">Agriculture in Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mining_in_Brazil" title="Mining in Brazil">Mining in Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Industry_in_Brazil" title="Industry in Brazil">Industry in Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Energy policy of Brazil">Energy policy of Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Oil_platform_P-51_(Brazil)-2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Oil_platform_P-51_%28Brazil%29-2.jpg/220px-Oil_platform_P-51_%28Brazil%29-2.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Oil_platform_P-51_%28Brazil%29-2.jpg/330px-Oil_platform_P-51_%28Brazil%29-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Oil_platform_P-51_%28Brazil%29-2.jpg/440px-Oil_platform_P-51_%28Brazil%29-2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2657" data-file-height="1772" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Oil_platform_P-51_(Brazil)-2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nP-51, an <a href="/wiki/Oil_platform" title="Oil platform">oil platform</a> of <a href="/wiki/Petrobras" title="Petrobras">Petrobras</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Brazil\'s diversified economy includes agriculture, industry, and a wide range of services.<sup id="cite_ref-BansalPhatak2009_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BansalPhatak2009-243">[243]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Brazil" title="Agriculture in Brazil">Agriculture</a> and allied sectors like <a href="/wiki/Forestry" title="Forestry">forestry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Logging" title="Logging">logging</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fishing" title="Fishing">fishing</a> accounted for 5.1% of the <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_GDP_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_GDP-244">[244]</a></sup> Brazil is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_producing_countries_of_agricultural_commodities" title="List of largest producing countries of agricultural commodities">largest producer</a> of oranges, coffee, sugar cane, cassava and sisal, soybeans and papayas.<sup id="cite_ref-Luck1998_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Luck1998-245">[245]</a></sup></p>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Industry_in_Brazil" title="Industry in Brazil">industry</a> \xe2\x80\x93 from <a href="/wiki/Automobile" class="mw-redirect" title="Automobile">automobiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steel" title="Steel">steel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Petrochemical" title="Petrochemical">petrochemicals</a> to <a href="/wiki/Computer" title="Computer">computers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aircraft" title="Aircraft">aircraft</a> and <a href="/wiki/Durable_good" title="Durable good">consumer durables</a> \xe2\x80\x93 accounted for 30.8% of the gross domestic product.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_GDP_244-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_GDP-244">[244]</a></sup> Industry is highly concentrated in metropolitan S\xc3\xa3o Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, <a href="/wiki/Campinas" title="Campinas">Campinas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porto_Alegre" title="Porto Alegre">Porto Alegre</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte" title="Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GiordanoLanzafame2005_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GiordanoLanzafame2005-246">[246]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Brazil is the world\'s <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_primary_energy_consumption_and_production" title="List of countries by total primary energy consumption and production">tenth largest</a> energy consumer with much of its energy coming from <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable sources</a>, particularly <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectricity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethanol" title="Ethanol">ethanol</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Itaipu_Dam" title="Itaipu Dam">Itaipu Dam</a> is the world\'s largest <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectric plant</a> by energy generation.<sup id="cite_ref-SchmidtOnyango2011_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SchmidtOnyango2011-247">[247]</a></sup> The first car with an ethanol engine was produced in 1978 and the first airplane engine running on ethanol in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-OECDDevelopment2001_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECDDevelopment2001-248">[248]</a></sup> Recent oil discoveries in the <a href="/wiki/Pre-salt_layer" title="Pre-salt layer">Pre-salt layer</a> have opened the door for a large increase in oil production.<sup id="cite_ref-BrainardMartinez-Diaz2009_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BrainardMartinez-Diaz2009-249">[249]</a></sup> The governmental agencies responsible for the energy policy are the Ministry of Mines and Energy, the National Council for Energy Policy, the <a href="/wiki/National_Agency_of_Petroleum,_Natural_Gas_and_Biofuels_(Brazil)" title="National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels (Brazil)">National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Electricity_Regulatory_Agency" title="Brazilian Electricity Regulatory Agency">National Agency of Electricity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-OECD2005_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD2005-250">[250]</a></sup></p>\n<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; overflow:hidden; width:auto; max-width:1108px;">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="">\n<div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Itaipu_%C3%A0_noite.jpg" class="image" title="The Itaipu Dam on the Paran\xc3\xa1 River, located on the border between Brazil and Paraguay, is the second largest of the world (the first is the Three Gorges Dam, in China). Approximately 75% of the Brazilian energy matrix, one of the cleanest in the world, comes from hydropower."><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Itaipu_%C3%A0_noite.jpg/1100px-Itaipu_%C3%A0_noite.jpg" width="1100" height="178" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Itaipu_%C3%A0_noite.jpg/1650px-Itaipu_%C3%A0_noite.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Itaipu_%C3%A0_noite.jpg/2200px-Itaipu_%C3%A0_noite.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4016" data-file-height="651" /></a></div>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Itaipu_%C3%A0_noite.jpg" title="File:Itaipu \xc3\xa0 noite.jpg"></a></div>\nThe <a href="/wiki/Itaipu_Dam" title="Itaipu Dam">Itaipu Dam</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_River" title="Paran\xc3\xa1 River">Paran\xc3\xa1 River</a>, located on the border between Brazil and Paraguay, is the second largest of the world (the first is the <a href="/wiki/Three_Gorges_Dam" title="Three Gorges Dam">Three Gorges Dam</a>, in <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>). Approximately 75% of the <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Energy policy of Brazil">Brazilian energy matrix</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/Clean_energy" class="mw-redirect" title="Clean energy">cleanest</a> in the world, comes from <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Brazil" title="Tourism in Brazil">Tourism in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Noronha_02.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Noronha_02.jpg/220px-Noronha_02.jpg" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Noronha_02.jpg/330px-Noronha_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Noronha_02.jpg/440px-Noronha_02.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3459" data-file-height="1946" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Noronha_02.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/Fernando_de_Noronha" title="Fernando de Noronha">Fernando de Noronha Archipelago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pernambuco" title="Pernambuco">Pernambuco</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class="thumb tleft">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cataratas_do_Igua%C3%A7u_-_Vista_de_cima_alt.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Cataratas_do_Igua%C3%A7u_-_Vista_de_cima_alt.jpg/220px-Cataratas_do_Igua%C3%A7u_-_Vista_de_cima_alt.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Cataratas_do_Igua%C3%A7u_-_Vista_de_cima_alt.jpg/330px-Cataratas_do_Igua%C3%A7u_-_Vista_de_cima_alt.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Cataratas_do_Igua%C3%A7u_-_Vista_de_cima_alt.jpg/440px-Cataratas_do_Igua%C3%A7u_-_Vista_de_cima_alt.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3781" data-file-height="2836" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Cataratas_do_Igua%C3%A7u_-_Vista_de_cima_alt.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/Iguazu_Falls" title="Iguazu Falls">Iguazu Falls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_(state)" title="Paran\xc3\xa1 (state)">Paran\xc3\xa1</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Argentina%E2%80%93Brazil_relations" title="Argentina\xe2\x80\x93Brazil relations">Brazil-Argentina border</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Tourism in Brazil is a growing sector and key to the economy of several regions of the country. The country had 6.36 million visitors in 2015, ranking in terms of the international tourist arrivals as the main destination in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a> and second in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> after <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup> Revenues from international tourists reached <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$6</span> billion in 2010, showing a recovery from the <a href="/wiki/Late-2000s_recession" class="mw-redirect" title="Late-2000s recession">2008\xe2\x80\x932009 economic crisis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-UNWTO2011_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNWTO2011-252">[252]</a></sup> Historical records of 5.4 million visitors and <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$6.8</span> billion in receipts were reached in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-MT1_2011_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MT1_2011-253">[253]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MT2_2011_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MT2_2011-254">[254]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Natural areas are its most popular tourism product, a combination of <a href="/wiki/Ecotourism" title="Ecotourism">ecotourism</a> with <a href="/wiki/Leisure" title="Leisure">leisure</a> and <a href="/wiki/Recreation" title="Recreation">recreation</a>, mainly sun and beach, and <a href="/wiki/Adventure_travel" title="Adventure travel">adventure travel</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Cultural_tourism" title="Cultural tourism">cultural tourism</a>. Among the most popular destinations are the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Rainforest" class="mw-redirect" title="Amazon Rainforest">Amazon Rainforest</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beach" title="Beach">beaches</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dune" title="Dune">dunes</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Northeast Region, Brazil">Northeast Region</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pantanal" title="Pantanal">Pantanal</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Center-West_Region,_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Center-West Region, Brazil">Center-West Region</a>, beaches at <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_(state)" title="Rio de Janeiro (state)">Rio de Janeiro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Santa_Catarina_(state)" title="Santa Catarina (state)">Santa Catarina</a>, cultural tourism in <a href="/wiki/Minas_Gerais" title="Minas Gerais">Minas Gerais</a> and business trips to <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a> city.<sup id="cite_ref-Palhares2012_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Palhares2012-255">[255]</a></sup></p>\n<p>In terms of the 2015 <a href="/wiki/Travel_and_Tourism_Competitiveness_Report" title="Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report">Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Index</a> (TTCI), which is a measurement of the factors that make it attractive to develop business in the travel and tourism industry of individual countries, Brazil ranked in the 28st place at the world\'s level, third in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>, after <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-TTCI2013_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TTCI2013-257">[257]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Brazil\'s main competitive advantages are its natural resources, which ranked 1st on this criteria out of all countries considered, and ranked 23rd for its cultural resources, due to its many <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_site" class="mw-redirect" title="World Heritage site">World Heritage sites</a>. The TTCI report notes Brazil\'s main weaknesses: its ground transport infrastructure remains underdeveloped (ranked 116th), with the quality of roads ranking in 105th place; and the country continues to suffer from a lack of price competitiveness (ranked 114th), due in part to high ticket taxes and airport charges, as well as high prices and high taxation. Safety and security have improved significantly: 75th in 2011, up from 128th in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-TTCI2013_257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TTCI2013-257">[257]</a></sup></p>\n<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_Organization" title="World Tourism Organization">World Tourism Organization</a> (WTO), international travel to Brazil accelerated in 2000, particularly during 2004 and 2005. However, in 2006 a slow-down took place, and international arrivals had almost no growth in 2007\xe2\x80\x9308.<sup id="cite_ref-WTO2007_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTO2007-258">[258]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EMBRATUR09_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EMBRATUR09-259">[259]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup></p>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Abismo_Anhumas,_Bonito,_MS.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG/220px-Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG/330px-Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG/440px-Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Abismo_Anhumas,_Bonito,_MS.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/Bonito,_Mato_Grosso_do_Sul" title="Bonito, Mato Grosso do Sul">Bonito</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mato_Grosso_do_Sul" title="Mato Grosso do Sul">Mato Grosso do Sul</a>. The rivers in the region are known for their <a href="/wiki/Crystal" title="Crystal">crystal</a> clear waters.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg/220px-Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg/330px-Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg/440px-Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5357" data-file-height="3571" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nThe city of <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> is featured in <a href="/wiki/Tourism" title="Tourism">tourism</a> in Brazil.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>In spite of this trend, revenues from international tourism continued to rise, from <a href="/wiki/USD" class="mw-redirect" title="USD">USD</a> 4 billion in 2005 to 5 billion in 2007, despite 330 000 fewer arrivals. This favorable trend is the result of the strong devaluation of the US dollar against the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Real" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian Real">Brazilian Real</a>, which began in 2004, but which makes Brazil a more expensive international destination.<sup id="cite_ref-Boletim0207_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boletim0207-261">[261]</a></sup> This trend changed in 2009, when both visitors and revenues fell as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a> of 2008\xe2\x80\x9309.<sup id="cite_ref-WTO2010_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTO2010-262">[262]</a></sup> By 2010, the industry had recovered, and arrivals grew above 2006 levels to 5.2 million international visitors, and receipts from these visitors reached USD 6 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-UNWTO2011_252-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNWTO2011-252">[252]</a></sup> In 2011 the historical record was reached with 5.4 million visitors and <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$6.8</span> billion in receipts.<sup id="cite_ref-MT1_2011_253-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MT1_2011-253">[253]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MT2_2011_254-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MT2_2011-254">[254]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Despite continuing record-breaking international tourism revenues, the number of Brazilian tourists travelling overseas has been growing steadily since 2003, resulting in a net negative <a href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_market" title="Foreign exchange market">foreign exchange</a> balance, as more money is spent abroad by Brazilians than comes in as receipts from international tourists visiting Brazil. Tourism expenditures abroad grew from USD 5.8 billion in 2006, to USD 8.2 billion in 2007, a 42% increase, representing a net deficit of USD 3.3 billion in 2007, as compared to USD 1.5 billion in 2006, a 125% increase from the previous year.<sup id="cite_ref-Boletim0308_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boletim0308-263">[263]</a></sup> This trend is caused by Brazilians taking advantage of the stronger <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_real" title="Brazilian real">Real</a> to travel and making relatively cheaper expenditures abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-Boletim0308_263-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boletim0308-263">[263]</a></sup> Brazilians traveling overseas in 2006 represented 4% of the country\'s population.<sup id="cite_ref-FIPE006_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FIPE006-264">[264]</a></sup></p>\n<p>In 2005, tourism contributed with 3.2% of the country\'s revenues from exports of goods and services, and represented 7% of direct and indirect employment in the Brazilian economy.<sup id="cite_ref-BID2006_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BID2006-265">[265]</a></sup> In 2006 direct employment in the sector reached 1.9 million people.<sup id="cite_ref-IPEA08_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IPEA08-266">[266]</a></sup> Domestic tourism is a fundamental market segment for the industry, as 51 million people traveled throughout the country in 2005,<sup id="cite_ref-FIPE007_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FIPE007-267">[267]</a></sup> and direct revenues from Brazilian tourists reached USD 22 billion,<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> 5.6 times more receipts than international tourists in 2005.</p>\n<p>In 2005, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Foz_do_Igua%C3%A7u" title="Foz do Igua\xc3\xa7u">Foz do Igua\xc3\xa7u</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Florian%C3%B3polis" title="Florian\xc3\xb3polis">Florian\xc3\xb3polis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia" title="Salvador, Bahia">Salvador</a> were the most visited cities by international tourists for leisure trips. The most popular destinations for business trips were <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Porto_Alegre" title="Porto Alegre">Porto Alegre</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EMBRATUR06_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EMBRATUR06-269">[269]</a></sup> In 2006 Rio de Janeiro and <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a> were the most popular destinations for business trips.</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Brazil" title="Science and technology in Brazil">Science and technology in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:30_Anos_Laborat%C3%B3rio_Sincrotron.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/30_Anos_Laborat%C3%B3rio_Sincrotron.jpg/220px-30_Anos_Laborat%C3%B3rio_Sincrotron.jpg" width="220" height="135" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/30_Anos_Laborat%C3%B3rio_Sincrotron.jpg/330px-30_Anos_Laborat%C3%B3rio_Sincrotron.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/30_Anos_Laborat%C3%B3rio_Sincrotron.jpg/440px-30_Anos_Laborat%C3%B3rio_Sincrotron.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7360" data-file-height="4518" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:30_Anos_Laborat%C3%B3rio_Sincrotron.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/Laborat%C3%B3rio_Nacional_de_Luz_S%C3%ADncrotron" title="Laborat\xc3\xb3rio Nacional de Luz S\xc3\xadncrotron">National Synchrotron Light Laboratory</a> in <a href="/wiki/Campinas" title="Campinas">Campinas</a>, <a href="/wiki/State_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" class="mw-redirect" title="State of S\xc3\xa3o Paulo">state of S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a>, the only <a href="/wiki/Particle_accelerator" title="Particle accelerator">particle accelerator</a> in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class="thumb tleft">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vls1-mockup-test.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Vls1-mockup-test.jpg/220px-Vls1-mockup-test.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Vls1-mockup-test.jpg/330px-Vls1-mockup-test.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Vls1-mockup-test.jpg/440px-Vls1-mockup-test.jpg 2x" data-file-width="620" data-file-height="413" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Vls1-mockup-test.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/VLS-1" title="VLS-1">VLS-1</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Alc%C3%A2ntara_Launch_Center" title="Alc\xc3\xa2ntara Launch Center">Alc\xc3\xa2ntara Launch Center</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Space_Agency" title="Brazilian Space Agency">Brazilian Space Agency</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Technological research in Brazil is largely carried out in public universities and research institutes, with the majority of funding for basic research coming from various government agencies.<sup id="cite_ref-DevelopmentStaff2006v_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DevelopmentStaff2006v-270">[270]</a></sup> Brazil\'s most esteemed technological hubs are the <a href="/wiki/Funda%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Oswaldo_Cruz" class="mw-redirect" title="Funda\xc3\xa7\xc3\xa3o Oswaldo Cruz">Oswaldo Cruz Institute</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Butantan" title="Instituto Butantan">Butantan Institute</a>, the Air Force\'s <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_General_Command_for_Aerospace_Technology" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian General Command for Aerospace Technology">Aerospace Technical Center</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Empresa_Brasileira_de_Pesquisa_Agropecu%C3%A1ria" class="mw-redirect" title="Empresa Brasileira de Pesquisa Agropecu\xc3\xa1ria">Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_for_Space_Research" title="National Institute for Space Research">INPE</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Scientific2010f_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scientific2010f-271">[271]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-HarveySmid2010_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HarveySmid2010-272">[272]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Space_Agency" title="Brazilian Space Agency">Brazilian Space Agency</a> has the most advanced space program in Latin America, with significant resources to launch vehicles, and manufacture of <a href="/wiki/Artificial_satellite" class="mw-redirect" title="Artificial satellite">satellite</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012.5Bhttps:.2F.2Fbooks.google.com.2Fbooks.3Fid.3DvP9jHaoL_s4C.26pg.3DPA628_628.5D_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012.5Bhttps:.2F.2Fbooks.google.com.2Fbooks.3Fid.3DvP9jHaoL_s4C.26pg.3DPA628_628.5D-273">[273]</a></sup> Owner of relative technological sophistication, the country develops <a href="/wiki/Submarine" title="Submarine">submarines</a>, aircraft, as well as being involved in space research, having a Vehicle Launch Center Light and being the only country in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a> the integrate team building <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a> (ISS).<sup id="cite_ref-NASA_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NASA-274">[274]</a></sup></p>\n<p>The country is also a pioneer in the search for oil in deep water, from where extracts 73% of its reserves. <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">Uranium</a> is enriched at the <a href="/wiki/Resende_Nuclear_Fuel_Factory" title="Resende Nuclear Fuel Factory">Resende Nuclear Fuel Factory</a>, mostly for research purposes (as Brazil obtains 88% from its electricity from <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectricity</a><sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[275]</a></sup>) and the country\'s first nuclear submarine will be delivered in 2015 (by France).<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup> Brazil is one of the three countries in Latin America<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup> with an operational <a href="/wiki/Synchrotron" title="Synchrotron">Synchrotron</a> Laboratory, a research facility on physics, chemistry, material science and life sciences. And Brazil is the only Latin American country to have a <a href="/wiki/Semiconductor" title="Semiconductor">semiconductor</a> company with its own <a href="/wiki/Semiconductor_fabrication_plant" title="Semiconductor fabrication plant">fabrication plant</a>, the <a href="/wiki/CEITEC" title="CEITEC">CEITEC</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup> According to the Global Information Technology Report 2009-2010 of the World Economic Forum, Brazil is the 61 world\'s largest developer of information technology.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[279]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Brazil also has a large number of outstanding scientific personalities. Among the most renowned Brazilian inventors are priests <a href="/wiki/Bartolomeu_de_Gusm%C3%A3o" title="Bartolomeu de Gusm\xc3\xa3o">Bartolomeu de Gusm\xc3\xa3o</a>, <a href="/wiki/Landell_de_Moura" title="Landell de Moura">Landell de Moura</a> and Francisco Jo\xc3\xa3o de Azevedo, besides <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Santos-Dumont" title="Alberto Santos-Dumont">Alberto Santos-Dumont</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Evaristo_Conrado_Engelberg" title="Evaristo Conrado Engelberg">Evaristo Conrado Engelberg</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-patentbritish_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-patentbritish-281">[281]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Dias_de_Abreu" class="mw-redirect" title="Manuel Dias de Abreu">Manuel Dias de Abreu</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Andreas_Pavel" title="Andreas Pavel">Andreas Pavel</a><sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[283]</a></sup> e N\xc3\xa9lio Jos\xc3\xa9 Nicolai.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[284]</a></sup> Brazilian science is represented by the likes of <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Lattes" title="C\xc3\xa9sar Lattes">C\xc3\xa9sar Lattes</a> (Brazilian <a href="/wiki/Physicist" title="Physicist">physicist</a> Pathfinder of <i><a href="/wiki/Pion" title="Pion">Pi Meson</a></i>),<sup id="cite_ref-Lattes_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lattes-285">[285]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A1rio_Schenberg" title="M\xc3\xa1rio Schenberg">M\xc3\xa1rio Schenberg</a> (considered the greatest theoretical physicist of Brazil),<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[286]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Leite_Lopes" title="Jos\xc3\xa9 Leite Lopes">Jos\xc3\xa9 Leite Lopes</a> (only Brazilian physicist holder of <i>UNESCO Science Prize</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[287]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Artur_%C3%81vila" class="mw-redirect" title="Artur \xc3\x81vila">Artur \xc3\x81vila</a> (the first Latin American winner of <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields Medal</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Fritz_M%C3%BCller" title="Fritz M\xc3\xbcller">Fritz M\xc3\xbcller</a> (pioneer in factual support the theory of evolution by Charles Darwin).<sup id="cite_ref-West.2C_David_A_2003_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-West.2C_David_A_2003-289">[289]</a></sup></p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Terminal_3_de_Guarulhos.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Terminal_3_de_Guarulhos.jpg/220px-Terminal_3_de_Guarulhos.jpg" width="220" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Terminal_3_de_Guarulhos.jpg/330px-Terminal_3_de_Guarulhos.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Terminal_3_de_Guarulhos.jpg/440px-Terminal_3_de_Guarulhos.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5022" data-file-height="3194" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Terminal_3_de_Guarulhos.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nTerminal 3 of the <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo%E2%80%93Guarulhos_International_Airport" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo\xe2\x80\x93Guarulhos International Airport">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo\xe2\x80\x93Guarulhos International Airport</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Brazil" title="List of the busiest airports in Brazil">busiest airport in the country</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BR116_Viaduto_em_Fortaleza.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/BR116_Viaduto_em_Fortaleza.jpg/220px-BR116_Viaduto_em_Fortaleza.jpg" width="220" height="211" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/BR116_Viaduto_em_Fortaleza.jpg/330px-BR116_Viaduto_em_Fortaleza.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/BR116_Viaduto_em_Fortaleza.jpg/440px-BR116_Viaduto_em_Fortaleza.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1065" data-file-height="1023" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BR116_Viaduto_em_Fortaleza.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/BR-116" title="BR-116">BR-116</a> in <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cear%C3%A1" title="Cear\xc3\xa1">Cear\xc3\xa1</a>, the longest <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Highway_System" title="Brazilian Highway System">highway</a> in the country, with 4,385&#160;km (2,725&#160;mi) of extension.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Port_Santos.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Port_Santos.jpg/220px-Port_Santos.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Port_Santos.jpg/330px-Port_Santos.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Port_Santos.jpg/440px-Port_Santos.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Port_Santos.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nAerial view of <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Santos" title="Port of Santos">Port of Santos</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo (state)">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a>, the busiest port in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[291]</a></sup></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Brazil" title="Transport in Brazil">Transport in Brazil</a></div>\n<p>Brazilian roads are the primary carriers of freight and passenger traffic. The road system totaled 1.98 million km (1.23 million mi) in 2002. The total of paved roads increased from 35,496&#160;km (22,056&#160;mi) (22,056&#160;mi) in 1967 to 184,140&#160;km (114,419&#160;mi) (114,425&#160;mi) in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup></p>\n<p>The first investments in road infrastructure have given up in the 1920s, the government of <a href="/wiki/Washington_Luis" class="mw-redirect" title="Washington Luis">Washington Luis</a>, being pursued in the governments of <a href="/wiki/Get%C3%BAlio_Vargas" title="Get\xc3\xbalio Vargas">Get\xc3\xbalio Vargas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eurico_Gaspar_Dutra" title="Eurico Gaspar Dutra">Eurico Gaspar Dutra</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[293]</a></sup> President <a href="/wiki/Juscelino_Kubitschek" title="Juscelino Kubitschek">Juscelino Kubitschek</a> (1956\xe2\x80\x9361), who designed and built the capital <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Bras\xc3\xadlia">Bras\xc3\xadlia</a>, was another supporter of highways. Kubitschek was responsible for the installation of major car manufacturers in the country (<a href="/wiki/Volkswagen" title="Volkswagen">Volkswagen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company" title="Ford Motor Company">Ford</a> and <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">General Motors</a> arrived in Brazil during his rule) and one of the points used to attract them was, of course, support for the construction of highways. With the implementation of <a href="/wiki/Fiat" class="mw-redirect" title="Fiat">Fiat</a> in 1976 ending an automobile market closed loop, from the end of the 1990s the country has received large foreign direct investments installing in its territory other major car manufacturers and utilities, such as <a href="/wiki/Iveco" title="Iveco">Iveco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Renault" title="Renault">Renault</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot" title="Peugeot">Peugeot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citroen" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroen">Citroen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honda" title="Honda">Honda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mitsubishi" title="Mitsubishi">Mitsubishi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a>, <a href="/wiki/BMW" title="BMW">BMW</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hyundai" title="Hyundai">Hyundai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">Toyota</a> among others.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup> Brazil is the seventh most important country in the <a href="/wiki/Auto_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Auto industry">auto industry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Brazil\'s <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport" title="Rail transport">railway</a> system has been declining since 1945, when emphasis shifted to <a href="/wiki/Highway" title="Highway">highway</a> construction. The total length of railway track was 30,875&#160;km (19,185&#160;mi) in 2002, as compared with 31,848&#160;km (19,789&#160;mi) in 1970. Most of the railway system belonged to the Federal Railroad Corporation RFFSA, which was privatized in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_Metro" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo Metro">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo Metro</a> was the first underground transit system in Brazil. The other metro systems are in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porto_Alegre" title="Porto Alegre">Porto Alegre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Recife" title="Recife">Recife</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte" title="Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Bras\xc3\xadlia">Bras\xc3\xadlia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Teresina" title="Teresina">Teresina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a>.</p>\n<p>The country has an extensive rail network of 28,538 kilometres (17,733 miles) in length, the tenth largest network in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-2012ciagini_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2012ciagini-297">[297]</a></sup> Currently, the Brazilian government, unlike the past, seeks to encourage this mode of transport; an example of this incentive is the project of the <a href="/wiki/Rio%E2%80%93S%C3%A3o_Paulo_high-speed_rail" title="Rio\xe2\x80\x93S\xc3\xa3o Paulo high-speed rail">Rio\xe2\x80\x93S\xc3\xa3o Paulo high-speed rail</a>, that will connect the two main cities of the country to carry passengers.</p>\n<p>There are about 2,500 <a href="/wiki/Airport" title="Airport">airports</a> in Brazil, including landing fields: the second largest number in the world, after the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo-Guarulhos_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo-Guarulhos International Airport">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo-Guarulhos International Airport</a>, near S\xc3\xa3o Paulo, is the largest and busiest airport with nearly 20 million passengers annually, while handling the vast majority of commercial traffic for the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Palhares2012x_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Palhares2012x-299">[299]</a></sup></p>\n<p>For freight transport <a href="/wiki/Waterways" class="mw-redirect" title="Waterways">waterways</a> are of importance, e.g. the <a href="/wiki/Free_Economic_Zone_of_Manaus" title="Free Economic Zone of Manaus">industrial zones of Manaus</a> can be reached only by means of the Solim\xc3\xb5es- Amazonas waterway (3,250 kilometres (2,020 miles) with 6 metres (20 feet) minimum depth). The country also has 50,000 kilometres (31,000 miles) of waterways.<sup id="cite_ref-2012ciagini_297-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2012ciagini-297">[297]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Coastal shipping links widely separated parts of the country. Bolivia and Paraguay have been given free <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">ports</a> at <a href="/wiki/Santos,_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Santos, S\xc3\xa3o Paulo">Santos</a>. Of the 36 deep-water ports, Santos, Itaja\xc3\xad, Rio Grande, Paranagu\xc3\xa1, Rio de Janeiro, Sepetiba, Vit\xc3\xb3ria, Suape, Manaus and S\xc3\xa3o Francisco do Sul are the most important.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup> Bulk carriers have to wait up to 18 days before being serviced, container ships 36,3 hours on average.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Brazil" title="Water supply and sanitation in Brazil">Water supply and sanitation in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:ETE_-_Esta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Tratamento_de_Esgoto_-_Una%C3%AD.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/ETE_-_Esta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Tratamento_de_Esgoto_-_Una%C3%AD.JPG/220px-ETE_-_Esta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Tratamento_de_Esgoto_-_Una%C3%AD.JPG" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/ETE_-_Esta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Tratamento_de_Esgoto_-_Una%C3%AD.JPG/330px-ETE_-_Esta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Tratamento_de_Esgoto_-_Una%C3%AD.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/ETE_-_Esta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Tratamento_de_Esgoto_-_Una%C3%AD.JPG/440px-ETE_-_Esta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Tratamento_de_Esgoto_-_Una%C3%AD.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2304" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:ETE_-_Esta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_Tratamento_de_Esgoto_-_Una%C3%AD.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\n<a href="/wiki/Water_treatment_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Water treatment plant">Water treatment plant</a> in <a href="/wiki/Una%C3%AD" title="Una\xc3\xad">Una\xc3\xad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minas_Gerais" title="Minas Gerais">Minas Gerais</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Among the achievements in the water supply and sanitation sector is an increase in access to water piped on premises from 79% to 92% between 1990 and 2010; an increase in access to <a href="/wiki/Improved_sanitation" title="Improved sanitation">Improved sanitation</a> from 68% to 79% in the same period;<sup id="cite_ref-JMP2008_302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JMP2008-302">[302]</a></sup> a functioning national system to finance water and sanitation infrastructure; a high level of cost recovery compared to most other developing countries; as well as a number of notable technical and financial innovations such as <a href="/wiki/Condominial_sewerage" title="Condominial sewerage">Condominial sewerage</a> and an output-based subsidy for treated wastewater called <a href="/wiki/PRODES" title="PRODES">PRODES</a>.</p>\n<p>Among the challenges is the still high number of poor Brazilians living in urban slums (<a href="/wiki/Favela" title="Favela">Favela</a>) and in rural areas without access to piped water or sanitation; <a href="/wiki/Water_scarcity" title="Water scarcity">water scarcity</a> in the Northeast of Brazil; <a href="/wiki/Water_pollution" title="Water pollution">water pollution</a>, especially in the South-East of the country; the low share of collected <a href="/wiki/Wastewater_treatment" title="Wastewater treatment">wastewater</a> that is being treated (35% in 2000); and long-standing tensions between the federal, state and municipal governments about their respective roles in the sector.</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Brazil" title="Health in Brazil">Health in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hospital_Albert_Einstein.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Hospital_Albert_Einstein.jpg/220px-Hospital_Albert_Einstein.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Hospital_Albert_Einstein.jpg/330px-Hospital_Albert_Einstein.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Hospital_Albert_Einstein.jpg/440px-Hospital_Albert_Einstein.jpg 2x" data-file-width="850" data-file-height="638" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Hospital_Albert_Einstein.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nThe <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein_Hospital" title="Albert Einstein Hospital">Albert Einstein Hospital</a> in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a> is one of the most well-known health units in Brazil.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The Brazilian <a href="/wiki/Public_health" title="Public health">public health</a> system, the <a href="/wiki/Sistema_%C3%9Anico_de_Sa%C3%BAde" title="Sistema \xc3\x9anico de Sa\xc3\xbade">Unified Health System</a> (SUS), is managed and provided by all levels of government,<sup id="cite_ref-ForgiaCouttolenc2008_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ForgiaCouttolenc2008-303">[303]</a></sup> being the largest system of this type in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[304]</a></sup> On the other hand, <a href="/wiki/Private_healthcare" title="Private healthcare">private healthcare</a> systems play a complementary role.<sup id="cite_ref-Wolper2004_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wolper2004-305">[305]</a></sup> Public health services are universal and offered to all citizens of the country for free. However, the construction and maintenance of health centers and hospitals are financed by taxes, and the country spends about 9% of its GDP on expenditures in the area. In 2009, the Brazilian territory had 1.72 doctors and 2.4 hospital beds for every 1,000 inhabitants.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>\n<p>Despite all the progress made since the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> system in 1988, there are still several public health problems in Brazil. In 2006, the main points to be solved were the high <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_infant_mortality_rate" title="List of countries by infant mortality rate">infant</a> (2.51%) and maternal mortality rates (73.1 deaths per 1000 births). The number of deaths from noncommunicable diseases, such as <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_diseases" class="mw-redirect" title="Cardiovascular diseases">cardiovascular diseases</a> (151.7 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants) and <a href="/wiki/Cancer" title="Cancer">cancer</a> (72.7 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants), also has a considerable impact on the health of the Brazilian population. Finally, external but preventable factors such as car accidents, violence and suicide caused 14.9% of all deaths in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[306]</a></sup> The Brazilian health system was ranked 125th among the 191 countries evaluated by the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO) in 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[307]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Brazil" title="Education in Brazil">Education in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg/220px-Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg/330px-Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg/440px-Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nClassroom in the main campus of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Campinas" title="University of Campinas">University of Campinas</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="S\xc3\xa3o Paulo (state)">S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution" title="Constitution">Federal Constitution</a> and the Law of Guidelines and Bases of National Education determine that the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Government" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal Government">Federal Government</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federated_state" title="Federated state">States</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_District" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal District">Federal District</a> and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities" class="mw-redirect" title="Municipalities">municipalities</a> must manage and organize their respective education systems. Each of these public educational systems is responsible for its own maintenance, which manages funds as well as the mechanisms and funding sources. The constitution reserves 25% of the state budget and 18% of federal taxes and municipal taxes for education.<sup id="cite_ref-Usa2005_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Usa2005-308">[308]</a></sup></p>\n<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Institute_of_Geography_and_Statistics" title="Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics">IBGE</a>, in 2011, the literacy rate of the population was 90.4%, meaning that 13 million (9.6% of population) people are still illiterate in the country; functional illiteracy has reached 21.6% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-Agency2010_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Agency2010-309">[309]</a></sup> Illiteracy is highest in the Northeast, where 19.9% of the population is illiterate.<sup id="cite_ref-Bank2001_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bank2001-310">[310]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Higher education starts with undergraduate or sequential <a href="/wiki/Course_(education)" title="Course (education)">courses</a>, which may offer different options of specialization in academic or professional careers. Depending on the choice, students can improve their educational background with courses of post-graduate studies or broad sense. To attend a higher education institution is required, by Law of Guidelines and Bases of Education, completing all levels of education suited to the needs of all students of teaching <a href="/wiki/Kindergarten" title="Kindergarten">kindergarten</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elementary_school" title="Elementary school">elementary</a> and medium, provided the student does not hold any disability, whether physical, <a href="/wiki/Mind" title="Mind">mental</a>, <a href="/wiki/Visual" class="mw-redirect" title="Visual">visual</a> or <a href="/wiki/Hearing_(sense)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hearing (sense)">hearing</a>.</p>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/University_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="University of S\xc3\xa3o Paulo">University of S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a> is the best <a href="/wiki/University" title="University">university</a> in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, according to <a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a>. Of the top 20 Latin Americans universities, eight are Brazilian. Most of them are <a href="/wiki/Public_university" title="Public university">public</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[311]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_communication">Media and communication<span id="Media"></span></span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Brazil" title="Telecommunications in Brazil">Telecommunications in Brazil</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Media_ownership_in_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Media ownership in Brazil">Media ownership in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg/220px-Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg/330px-Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg/440px-Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="683" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nFormer President <a href="/wiki/Dilma_Rousseff" title="Dilma Rousseff">Dilma Rousseff</a> at <i><a href="/wiki/Jornal_Nacional" title="Jornal Nacional">Jornal Nacional</a></i> news program. <a href="/wiki/Rede_Globo" title="Rede Globo">Rede Globo</a> is the second largest commercial television network of the world.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[312]</a></sup></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The Brazilian press has its beginnings in 1808 with the arrival of the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Braganza#Realm_in_Brazil" title="House of Braganza">Portuguese royal family</a> to Brazil, hitherto forbidden any activity of the press \xe2\x80\x93 was the publication of newspapers or books. The Brazilian press was officially born in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> on 13 May 1808, with the creation of the Royal Printing, National Press by the <a href="/wiki/Prince_Regent" class="mw-redirect" title="Prince Regent">Prince Regent</a> <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_VI_of_Portugal" class="mw-redirect" title="Jo\xc3\xa3o VI of Portugal">Dom Jo\xc3\xa3o</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Echevarr.C3.ADaPupo-Walker1996_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Echevarr.C3.ADaPupo-Walker1996-313">[313]</a></sup></p>\n<p>The <i>Gazeta do Rio de Janeiro</i>, the first newspaper published in the country, began to circulate on 10 September 1808.<sup id="cite_ref-Johnston2003_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Johnston2003-314">[314]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_the_world_by_circulation" class="mw-redirect" title="List of newspapers in the world by circulation">largest newspapers</a> nowadays are <i><a href="/wiki/Folha_de_S.Paulo" title="Folha de S.Paulo">Folha de S.Paulo</a></i> (from the state of S\xc3\xa3o Paulo), <i>Super Not\xc3\xadcia</i> (Minas Gerais 296.799), <i><a href="/wiki/O_Globo" title="O Globo">O Globo</a></i> (RJ 277.876) and <i><a href="/wiki/O_Estado_de_S._Paulo" title="O Estado de S. Paulo">O Estado de S. Paulo</a></i> (SP 235.217).<sup id="cite_ref-Vincent2003B_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vincent2003B-315">[315]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Radio broadcasting began on 7 September 1922, with a speech by then President Pessoa, and was formalized on 20 April 1923 with the creation of "Radio Society of Rio de Janeiro."<sup id="cite_ref-McCann2004_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McCann2004-316">[316]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Television in Brazil began officially on 18 September 1950, with the founding of <a href="/wiki/TV_Tupi" class="mw-redirect" title="TV Tupi">TV Tupi</a> by <a href="/wiki/Assis_Chateaubriand" title="Assis Chateaubriand">Assis Chateaubriand</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ward2007_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ward2007-317">[317]</a></sup> Since then television has grown in the country, creating large public networks such as Globo, SBT, Record and Bandeirantes. Today it is the most important factor in popular culture of Brazilian society, indicated by research showing that as much as 67%<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[318]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup> of the general population follow the same daily <a href="/wiki/Soap_opera" title="Soap opera">soap opera</a> broadcast. Digital Television, using the <a href="/wiki/SBTVD" class="mw-redirect" title="SBTVD">SBTVD</a> standard (based on the Japanese standard <a href="/wiki/ISDB-T" class="mw-redirect" title="ISDB-T">ISDB-T</a>), was adopted 29 June 2006 and launched on 2 November 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-Alencar2009_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alencar2009-320">[320]</a></sup> In May 2010, Brazil launched <a href="/wiki/TV_Brasil_Internacional" title="TV Brasil Internacional">TV Brasil Internacional</a>, an international <a href="/wiki/Television_station" title="Television station">television station</a>, initially broadcasting to 49 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[321]</a></sup></p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Brazil" title="Demographics of Brazil">Demographics of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazilian people">Brazilian people</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Brazil" title="Immigration to Brazil">Immigration to Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Brazilian_states_by_population_density" title="List of Brazilian states by population density">List of Brazilian states by population density</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright">\n<div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png/300px-ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png" width="300" height="305" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png/450px-ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2e/ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png 2x" data-file-width="593" data-file-height="603" /></a>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>\nPopulation density of Brazilian municipalities.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The population of Brazil, as recorded by the 2008 PNAD, was approximately 190 million<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[322]</a></sup> (22.31 inhabitants per square kilometre or 57.8/sq&#160;mi), with a ratio of men to women of 0.95:1<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[323]</a></sup> and 83.75% of the population defined as urban.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[324]</a></sup> The population is heavily concentrated in the Southeastern (79.8 million inhabitants) and Northeastern (53.5 million inhabitants) regions, while the two most extensive regions, the Center-West and the North, which together make up 64.12% of the Brazilian territory, have a total of only 29.1 million inhabitants.</p>\n<p>The first census
